groups.label: Mexican/Chicano, Undifferentiated Hispanic, Central Americans, South Americans
Asian, SE Asian, Vietnamese, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Indonesian, Malaysian, Other Asian
Pacific Islanders, Filipino, Hawaiian, Samoan, Tongan, Melanesian, Fijian, Micronesian, Chamorro, Guam
Caribbean, Haitian, Dominican Republic, Bahamian, Jamaican, Trinidadians, Other Caribbean
European Nationality (Italian, Irish, German Americans), Other European Ethnic

forms.label: Information distribution, tabling/ petition gathering, lobbying, letter-writing campaign, teach-ins.
Symbolic Display; e.g. Menorah, Creche Scene, graffiti, cross burnings, signs, standing displays

Conflict, Attack or Clash, no instigator (distinct from codes 11 or 12).  This includes any boundary conflict in which no instigator can be identified, i.e. black/white conflicts, abortion/anti-abortion conflicts.  Often, no claims will be discernable in the activity.  Form code 17 will most likely be used with “no target” (question 18 on the code sheet).
Lawsuit, legal maneuver by social movement organization or group
Other Form, not on this list.
Missing Information on Form of Event

activities.label: bannering or hanging banners on buildings, bridges, and so on.
bicycling as part of a procession in protest of something
candle-lighting or carrying or displaying candles
canvassing, asking for votes, signatures, money, opinions
discussion must be public and collective
dramaturgical presentation skit, street theater, guerilla theater,  theatrical event, use of puppets, mimes, clowns
fasting hunger strike, usually identified by placards, banners, leaflets.
petitioning both obtaining signatures and presentation of petitions, letters signature
photo exhibiting usually of atrocities or of victims who are focus of the protest
holding signs, picket line, placarding, human bill-boarding, informational picketing
reading or recitation of lists of names or of important documents (e.g., The Declaration of Independence or the Bible)
selling buttons, bumper-stickers, books, frisbees bearing demo info, and so on.
silence references to deliberate, designated periods of silence, silent worship, silent vigil
speechmaking references to speech making, speakers, testifying, witnessing, short talk, address, sermon, and so on.
sloganeering/chanting chanting same small sets of words (e.g., “Hell No, We Won’t Go…”)
vigiling silent protest holding placards, banners
worshipping church service format of a rally or demonstration.
wreathing laying wreaths or floral arrangements on statues or memorials
Displaying Goods/Symbolic Displays differ from tabling (above) in that this ACT to be used with artistic display of information.
Musical and/or Vocal Performance by celebrities or participants
Filming events at gathering or photographing event
Recruiting or evangelizing (e.g., attempt to get new members)
Lobbying any mention of lobbying, local, state, fed government
Polling report of polling attitudes regarding social movement claim
Torch-passing or passing of other item in relay
Civil Disobedience engaging in currently illegal as protest
Withholding obligations (e.g., refusing to go to school, work, pay rent /utilities/taxes, obey the draft)
Walk Out Not strikes, but walking out of meetings, graduation ceremonies, etc.
Lawsuits and other legal maneuvers such as a trial, filing brief, and son on.

labels.description: Name of article coder
Date of article coding
Name of newspaper
labels.values/reference to appendix: This is always entered as NYT

labels.description: The publication date of an article is represented by separate variables for month, day, and year. This variable represents the two-digit month of article.
The publication date of an article is represented by separate variables for month, day, and year. This variable represents the two-digit day of article.
The publication date of an article is represented by separate variables for month, day, and year. This variable represents the four-digit year of article
The date on which an event takes place is represented by seperate variables for month, day, and year. This variable represents the two-digit month of an event.
The date on which an event takes place is represented by seperate variables for month, day, and year. This variable represents the two-digit month of an event.
The date on which an event takes place is represented by seperate variables for month, day, and year. This variable represents the four-digit year of the event.
Unique identifying number for event
labels.values/reference to appendix: Event ID is set in the form yymmnnn, where yy is the two-digit year, mm is the two-digit month, and nnn is an integer incremented for each event in a given month. For example, 8707001 represents the first event for the month of July, 1987.

labels.description: The number of articles written on a given event
labels.values/reference to appendix: In many cases, events are covered by multiple articles, either on subsequent dates (as in follow-up articles), or in other related stories. This variable reflects the total number of identified articles covering a single given event.

labels.description: The full title of the coded article
Number of days that an event lasted, coded to the greatest integer.

labels.variable title: Did this event occur in some previous month?
labels.description: This variable serves as a flag for events that occurred previously and may be already coded. All of these were checked to ensure no double-coding of events.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 0 = Event occurred in the same month as the report or if event occurred on last day of month, and was reported on the first day of the subsequent month. 1 = Event occurred in the previous month and was checked to be sure it was not a duplicate of a previously-coded event.

labels.description: Narrative describing who participated in the event
labels.values/reference to appendix: This is missing for events from years 1968 to 1973.

labels.description: Narrative describing what happened at the event.
labels.values/reference to appendix: This is missing for events from years 1968 to 1973.

labels.description: Narrative describing the location of the event.
labels.values/reference to appendix: This is missing for events from years 1968 to 1973.

labels.description: Narrative description of the party against whom the event was directed.
labels.values/reference to appendix: This is missing for events from years 1968 to 1973.

labels.description: Narrative description of the purpose of the event.
labels.values/reference to appendix: This is missing for events from years 1968 to 1973.

labels.variable title: Why is this a Collective Action or SM Activity?
labels.description: Narrative description of the collective nature of the event.
labels.values/reference to appendix: Events are described as consisting of either collective claims-making or racial/ethnic violence.  This is missing for events from years 1968 to 1973.

labels.description: The page number on which the article appears
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n

labels.description: The section of the newspaper in which the article appears
labels.values/reference to appendix: Usually an integer, 1-n, but some sections may be alphanumeric (eg, “A” or “C”).

labels.description: A count of the number of paragraphs in the article. When an event is covered in multiple articles, this count is updated to reflect the total coverage across all articles.
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n

labels.description: staten is is a count of the total number of states in which the event took place. This number can be greater than 4, which is the number of states recorded for each event.
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n

labels.description: state1-state4 allow for the recording of up to four states in which the event took place
state1-state4 allow for the recording of up to four states in which the event took place
state1-state4 allow for the recording of up to four states in which the event took place
state1-state4 allow for the recording of up to four states in which the event took place
cityn records the total number of cities in which the event took place; cityn can be greater than 2, which is the total number of cities recorded in the event data
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n

labels.description: city1 and city2 allow for the recording of two cities where the event occurred.
city1 and city2 allow for the recording of two cities where the event occurred.
neighn is the total number of neighborhoods in which an event took place. Events are frequently describes as moving from a main street to a courthouse, for example.
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n

labels.description: The names of neighborhoods or other locations in which an event took place. This is also used to record the name or a college or university when protest took place at an institution.

labels.variable title: Was exact number of participants reported?
labels.description: Event participation is taken either from reported figures or inferred from textual clues (“hundreds”; “dozens”; “a few”). Particd records whether the number of participants was reported in the article or estimated by the coder
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if exact number of participants is reported, 0 otherwise

labels.description: The exact number of participants reported as taking part in the event
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n

labels.description: If the exact number of participants is not known, a value is selected from a general range
labels.values/reference to appendix: If number of participants is estimated, values are assigned according to the following categories: 1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6 – Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Events are coded as having been initiated by members of identifiable social, racial, or ethnic groups (such as women, students, or Native Americans). This value records the  number of distinct initiating groups (up to 3) of the event. Having two group characteristics allows for the recording of “black men,” “female students,” or “elderly residents,” for example, as initiating groups.

labels.variable title: The first characteristic of initiating groups 1 to 3
labels.description: The first characteristic of initiating groups 1 to 3
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF INITIATING GROUPS for a full list of characteristics

labels.variable title: The first characteristic of initiating groups 1 to 3
labels.description: The first characteristic of initiating groups 1 to 3
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF INITIATING GROUPS for a full list of characteristics

labels.variable title: The first characteristic of initiating groups 1 to 3
labels.description: The first characteristic of initiating groups 1 to 3
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF INITIATING GROUPS for a full list of characteristics

labels.variable title: The second characteristic, if given, of initating groups 1 to 3.
labels.description: The second characteristic, if given, of initating groups 1 to 3.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF INITIATING GROUPS for a full list of characteristics

labels.variable title: The second characteristic, if given, of initating groups 1 to 3.
labels.description: The second characteristic, if given, of initating groups 1 to 3.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF INITIATING GROUPS for a full list of characteristics

labels.variable title: The second characteristic, if given, of initating groups 1 to 3.
labels.description: The second characteristic, if given, of initating groups 1 to 3.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF INITIATING GROUPS for a full list of characteristics

labels.variable title: Was there a clearly definable target?
labels.description: This value represents whether the target of the event was clearly identifiable.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if target is clear, 0 otherwise

labels.description: How many targets were identified?
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n, if targd = 1

labels.variable title: If yes, what was the main target?
labels.description: Targ1 and targ2 represent up to two of the event's targets
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Government/State; 2 – Private/Business; 3- University/School; 4 – Foreign Government/State; 5 – Medical Facility/Organization; 6 – Other; 7 – Ethnic/Racial Group

labels.variable title: If yes, what was the main target?
labels.description: Targ1 and targ2 represent up to two of the event's targets
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Government/State; 2 – Private/Business; 3- University/School; 4 – Foreign Government/State; 5 – Medical Facility/Organization; 6 – Other; 7 – Ethnic/Racial Group

labels.description: If targ1 or targ2 is coded as 7, then ertarg1 must be entered to represent the ethnic or racial target or the event. If there is more than one ethnic/racial target, then ertarg2 must also be coded. Note that ertarg2 is only coded when there are two such targets; it does not correspond to targ2.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF TARGETS OF COLLECTIVE ACTION for a full list of ethnic/racial targets

labels.description: If targ1 or targ2 is coded as 7, then ertarg1 must be entered to represent the ethnic or racial target or the event. If there is more than one ethnic/racial target, then ertarg2 must also be coded. Note that ertarg2 is only coded when there are two such targets; it does not correspond to targ2.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF TARGETS OF COLLECTIVE ACTION for a full list of ethnic/racial targets

labels.variable title: Were specific organizations mentioned as participating in the event?
labels.description: This is a dummy variable coding whether specific organizations were described as actually being involved in the event (not observing, not commenting, but participating)
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if named organizations participated, 0 otherwise

labels.description: The number of organizations listed as taking part.
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n, if smonamed = 1

labels.description: smoname1-smoname4 allow for the coding of up to four names of organizations.
smoname1-smoname4 allow for the coding of up to four names of organizations.
smoname1-smoname4 allow for the coding of up to four names of organizations.
smoname1-smoname4 allow for the coding of up to four names of organizations.

labels.variable title: What was the main claim or demand of Protesters?
labels.description: claim1 through claim4 record the most salient reasons for the event or issues that caused protesters to take part.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF CLAIMS for a full list of event claims

labels.variable title: What was the main claim or demand of Protesters?
labels.description: claim1 through claim4 record the most salient reasons for the event or issues that caused protesters to take part.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF CLAIMS for a full list of event claims

labels.variable title: What was the main claim or demand of Protesters?
labels.description: claim1 through claim4 record the most salient reasons for the event or issues that caused protesters to take part.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF CLAIMS for a full list of event claims

labels.variable title: What was the main claim or demand of Protesters?
labels.description: claim1 through claim4 record the most salient reasons for the event or issues that caused protesters to take part.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF CLAIMS for a full list of event claims

labels.description: Each claim has a valence, or orientation of protesters to the issue. Claim1 corresponds to val1, claim2 to val2, and so on.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Protesters are acting for or in favor of the issue represented by the claim; 2 – Protesters are acting against or in opposition to the issue represented by the claim code; 3 – The valence of the protesters' relationship to the claim code is unknown or not applicable

labels.description: Each claim has a valence, or orientation of protesters to the issue. Claim1 corresponds to val1, claim2 to val2, and so on.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Protesters are acting for or in favor of the issue represented by the claim; 2 – Protesters are acting against or in opposition to the issue represented by the claim code; 3 – The valence of the protesters' relationship to the claim code is unknown or not applicable

labels.description: Each claim has a valence, or orientation of protesters to the issue. Claim1 corresponds to val1, claim2 to val2, and so on.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Protesters are acting for or in favor of the issue represented by the claim; 2 – Protesters are acting against or in opposition to the issue represented by the claim code; 3 – The valence of the protesters' relationship to the claim code is unknown or not applicable

labels.description: Each claim has a valence, or orientation of protesters to the issue. Claim1 corresponds to val1, claim2 to val2, and so on.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Protesters are acting for or in favor of the issue represented by the claim; 2 – Protesters are acting against or in opposition to the issue represented by the claim code; 3 – The valence of the protesters' relationship to the claim code is unknown or not applicable

labels.variable title: What was the main form of the event?
labels.description: Form1-form4 code the primary shape that the event took; form is the general structure, such as a march or a demonstration, in which more specific activities take place. Form1 is the primary or dominant form.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF FORMS for a full list of form codes

labels.variable title: What was the main form of the event?
labels.description: Form1-form4 code the primary shape that the event took; form is the general structure, such as a march or a demonstration, in which more specific activities take place. Form1 is the primary or dominant form.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF FORMS for a full list of form codes

labels.variable title: What was the main form of the event?
labels.description: Form1-form4 code the primary shape that the event took; form is the general structure, such as a march or a demonstration, in which more specific activities take place. Form1 is the primary or dominant form.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF FORMS for a full list of form codes

labels.variable title: What was the main form of the event?
labels.description: Form1-form4 code the primary shape that the event took; form is the general structure, such as a march or a demonstration, in which more specific activities take place. Form1 is the primary or dominant form.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF FORMS for a full list of form codes

labels.variable title: What was the main type of activity?
labels.description: Participants may engage in a number of different activities at any given event. Act1-act4 record these, with act1 coding the dominant or primary activity, such as picketing, shouting, or leafleting.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF ACTIVITIES for a full list of activity codes

labels.variable title: What was the main type of activity?
labels.description: Participants may engage in a number of different activities at any given event. Act1-act4 record these, with act1 coding the dominant or primary activity, such as picketing, shouting, or leafleting.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF ACTIVITIES for a full list of activity codes

labels.variable title: What was the main type of activity?
labels.description: Participants may engage in a number of different activities at any given event. Act1-act4 record these, with act1 coding the dominant or primary activity, such as picketing, shouting, or leafleting.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF ACTIVITIES for a full list of activity codes

labels.variable title: What was the main type of activity?
labels.description: Participants may engage in a number of different activities at any given event. Act1-act4 record these, with act1 coding the dominant or primary activity, such as picketing, shouting, or leafleting.
labels.values/reference to appendix: See LIST OF ACTIVITIES for a full list of activity codes

labels.description: viold is a dummy variable representing whether protesters used violence at the event
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if protesters engaged in violence, 0 otherwise

labels.description: If protesters were violent, violtype describes what violent activity they engaged in.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Weapons (rocks, bombs, guns, firebombs, bricks, stones); 2 – Physical or hand-to-hand violence; 3 – Other; 4 – Weapons and physical violence; 5 – Weapons and other; 6 – Physical and other; 7 – Weapons, physical, and other types of violence

Rformat.labels: Weapons (rocks, bombs, guns, firebombs, bricks, stones)
Weapons, physical, and other types of violence

labels.description: Records whether identifiable counter-protesters were also at the site of the event at the same time as the event.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if counterdemonstrators were present, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Records whether police were reported to be at the event
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if police were present, 0 otherwise

labels.variable title: Did police take any kind of action?
labels.description: Police may direct protesters behind barricades, disperse protesters, make arrests, or engage in violence. If they take any action, this value is coded.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if police clearly engaged in any activity beyond simply being present

labels.variable title: Was physical force used by police?
labels.description: This dummy value represents whether police used any physical tactics during their activity at the event
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if police clearly used force

labels.description: This dummy value represents whether police engaged in any violent tactics such as attacking protesters, or used equipment such as guns, tear gas, nightsticks, or riot control equipment.
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if police used any violent means in the course of their activity at the protest. If police4 is coded as 1, police1 through police3 must be coded 1.

labels.description: If any arrests were made, this dummy variable is coded to represent whether the number of arrests is known or estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if the number of arrests is estimated, 0 if the exact number of arrests is known. If no arrests were made, this variable is left uncoded.

labels.description: Exact number of arrests reported to have been made
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n, if arrestd = 0

labels.description: arrestes is coded when the number of arrests made is estimated according to textual clues such as “group,” “dozens,” or “hundreds.”
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6 – Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: This dummy variable represents whether or not the article refers to property damage (broken windows, burned buildings, etc) taking place in the course of the event
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if property damage is reported, 0 otherwise

labels.variable title: Dollar amount of damage, if reported
labels.description: The value of property damage, if any, is often reported in news coverage.
labels.values/reference to appendix: Integer, 1-n, in dollars, if propdam = 1

labels.description: Dummy variable reporting if any injuries are reported to have been incurred in the event
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if injuries took place, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to protesters is known or can be estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6 – Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to protesters is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to bystanders is known or can be estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6 – Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to bystanders is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to police is known or can be estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6 – Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to police is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to others (such as counterprotesters) is known
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6 – Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Coded if the number of injuries to others is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise

labels.description: deaths is assumed to be 0 if not explicitly stated in the article
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if deaths are specifically stated, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to protesters is known or can be estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to protesters is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to bystanders is known or can be estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to bystanders is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to police is known or can be estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6

Rformat.labels: Tens of thousands (10,000 or more people)

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to police is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to others (such as counterprotesters) is known or can be estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: Estimates are taken from midpoints of the following categories:  1 – Small, few handful (1-9 people); 2 – Group, committee (10-49 people); 3 – Large, gathering (50-99 people); 4 – Hundreds, mass, mob (100-999 people); 5 – Thousands (1,000-9,999 people); 6

labels.description: Coded if the number of deaths to others is estimated
labels.values/reference to appendix: 1 if it is an estimate, 0 otherwise
